column4: I need some help (who doesn't...), I opened up 81 workspaces just for the hell of it, and my system was not very happy at all. It reverted back to 36, and now that number is static, I can't change it (also, the "preferences" window for workspaces flickers). Now none of my windows have the bars around them with the X, minimize, maximize, etc. Any ideas?
title bar vanished = compiz or metacity crashed.. alt-f2 and do 'compiz --replace'
which may explain the other issues also
thank you sir. I'll give it a try.
or try 'metacity --replace'
compiz --repalace "xterm Xt error: Can't open display: %s"  and metacity --replace "Window manager error: Unable to open X display". Not sure what these mean?
sounds like something very weird crashed. it may be best to just reboot.
I've rebooted several times. The other users on the system work fine, just the one which tried to open 81 workspaces.
perhaps its time to reset your desktop settings,. you could start with the panels.
no dice. Do you know if there's a way to set the number of workspaces via terminal?
its in a gconf setting somewhere.. personally i would reset all teh gnome settings by deleting the various .gnome* and .gconf* directories.. and start with a clean desktop
there may be some '.compiz' directories somewhere also with settings for it.
if I nuke .gnome*, uh, what do I do after that? :\
log out/back in - it should reset gnome back to the defaults.. you DO understand this will delete all your gnome settings...
of course.
the settings are  getting a bit scattered in ways these days.. but its better then it was years ago at least.
i tend to use 'mc' from a console to clean out these things.   im not sure if removeing the settings while running gnome is that good an idea.
I've dropped to a terminal.
that did the trick! Thanks loads for your help, I appreciate it.
the 'ubuntu-tweak' tool is supposed to have some sort of 'archive your settings' feature that lets you restore back to a known point. BUt ive not tried/seen the feature yet.
it would be nioce if therre was some tool included in ubuntu to let you reset the 'core' settings that often cause issues
